Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A key legislative aide has just called and has ten minutes to talk right now about the bill you are campaigning for.
Story: I glance at the clock, feeling the weight of the evening pressing in. My boyfriend is in the kitchen, setting out the takeout containers we picked up for our one open night together before I leave for a week of travel. He’s been looking forward to this—just us, no distractions, a rare pause in our hectic lives. I promised him my full attention tonight. My phone buzzes, and I see the name of the legislative aide flash across the screen. My heart jumps. This is the call I’ve been waiting for—the chance to make a real impact on the bill I’ve poured months of energy into. The aide only has ten minutes, right now, and I know how crucial this conversation could be. I look at my boyfriend, his face expectant, and then at my phone, my mind racing. The demands of both worlds crash together inside me, and I feel the tension coil in my chest. I want to be present for him, to keep my promise, but I also can’t ignore the responsibility I feel to the cause and the people counting on me. My hand hovers over the phone, torn between two parts of myself.
